title: Plucky turkey makes deer keep their distance by flapping its wings and charging at them
text:
This is the hilarious moment a feisty turkey flapped its feathers and charged at grazing deer in a bid to force the animals to leave its patch of grass.

Anthony Landreth was hunting deer when he captured the determined bird aggressively jumping into one deer's face in Bolivar, west Tennessee.

In the clip, the deer watches as the wild turkey edges closer and makes a leap towards it.

A wild turkey flares its tail feathers and tries to intimidate a deer in Bolivar, west Tennessee

The white-tailed deer leaps backwards to escape the turkey which flies dramatically into its face and waves its fan-shaped tail.

The bird lunges forward and widens its wings and flaps - signalling that it has encountered a threat, in the clip shared on October 23.

The bird persists at leaping at the deer in an attempt to intimidate and seconds later the animal finally gets the message and decides to saunter off.

Moments later the turkey is outnumbered but this is not enough to put it off from marking its territory. The bird continues to lunge at the deer

But then the deer reappears with a friend, so again turkey launches forward and the two deer are sent scurrying away.

Moments later, five deer are seen grazing and the turkey still persists on intimidating despite being outnumbered.

Despite being outnumbered by the white-tailed deer, the turkey persists on following it and jumping in its face, in the clip uploaded on October 23. Turkeys will act aggressively if they feel an animal lower than them them in the pecking order

Landreth, who is part of the West Tennessee Deer Hunters group, posted the video to Facebook with the caption: 'This turkey doesn’t like to play reindeer games, lol!!'

People have been quick to share their witty responses to the turkey who appears to be throwing its weight around in Bolivar.

One viewer, Tracye Diane Simmons wrote: 'Somebody woke up on the wrong side of the roost!!!'

Corey Birmingham added: 'Great video!!! She was cocky this morning.'

According to the Massachusetts state website, wild turkey aggression can be linked to establishing dominance in their flock: 'Wild turkeys live in flocks organized by "pecking order".'

Turkey's will act aggressively if they feel an animal they have encountered is lower than them them in that pecking order.

Each bird is dominant over or 'pecks on' birds of lesser social status.

Wild turkeys can fly up to 55 miles per hour and run up to 25 miles per hour.
description: A wild turkey was filmed jumping into the faces of grazing deer to get them to back off in Bolivar, west Tennessee, on October 23.
